com.localytics.android

Class Localytics

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.localytics.android.Localytics

  • public class Localytics
extends java.lang.Object
    All calls to the Localytics library go through this singleton.

      • integrate

        public static void integrate(Context context)
        Integrates Localytics and initializes the Handlers.
        Parameters:
        context - The context used to access resources on behalf of the app. Cannot be null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if context is an Activity context or null, if LOCALYTICS_APP_KEY in AndroidManifest.xml is null or empty, or if PushReceiver is declared in AndroidManifest.xml but PushTrackingActivity isn't declared

      • integrate

        public static void integrate(Context context,
             java.lang.String localyticsKey)
        Integrates Localytics and initializes the Handlers.
        Parameters:
        context - The context used to access resources on behalf of the app. Cannot be null.
        localyticsKey - The unique key for each application generated at www.localytics.com.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if context is an Activity context or null, if LOCALYTICS_APP_KEY in AndroidManifest.xml is null or empty and localyticsKey is null or empty, or if PushReceiver is declared in AndroidManifest.xml but PushTrackingActivity isn't declared

      • upload

        public static void upload()
        Initiates an upload of all Localytics data. This should be done early in the process life in order to guarantee as much time as possible for slow connections to complete. It is necessary to do this even if the user has opted out because this is how the opt out is transported to the webservice.

      • setOptedOut

        public static void setOptedOut(boolean newOptOut)
        Sets the Localytics opt-out state for this application. This call is not necessary and is provided for people who wish to allow their users the ability to opt out of data collection. It can be called at any time. Passing true causes all further data collection to stop, and an opt-out event to be sent to the server so the user's data is removed from the charts.
        There are very serious implications to the quality of your data when providing an opt out option. For example, users who have opted out will appear as never returning, causing your new/returning chart to skew.
        If two instances of the same application are running, and one is opted in and the second opts out, the first will also become opted out, and neither will collect any more data.
        If a session was started while the app was opted out, the session open event has already been lost. For this reason, all sessions started while opted out will not collect data even after the user opts back in or else it taints the comparisons of session lengths and other metrics.
        Parameters:
        newOptOut - True if the user should be be opted out and have all his Localytics data deleted.
        See Also:
        isOptedOut()

      • isOptedOut

        public static boolean isOptedOut()
        Get the opted in/out state.
        Returns:
        True if opted out; false otherwise.
        See Also:
        setOptedOut(boolean)

      • openSession

        public static void openSession()
        Opens the Localytics session. The session should be opened before tagEvent(String), tagEvent(String, java.util.Map), tagEvent(String, java.util.Map), or tagScreen(String) are called.

        If a new session is opened shortly--within a few seconds--after an earlier session is closed, Localytics will reconnect to the previous session (effectively causing the previous close to be ignored). This ensures that as a user moves from Activity to Activity in an app, that is considered a single session. When a session is reconnected, the customDimensions for the initial open are kept and dimensions for the second open are ignored.

        If for any reason open is called more than once without an intervening call to closeSession(), subsequent calls to open will be ignored.

      • closeSession

        public static void closeSession()
        Closes the Localytics session. Once a session has been opened via openSession(), close the session when data collection is complete.

        If close is called without open having ever been called, the close has no effect. Similarly, once a session is closed, subsequent calls to close will be ignored.

      • tagEvent

        public static void tagEvent(java.lang.String eventName)
        Behaves identically to calling tagEvent(eventName, null, 0).
        Parameters:
        eventName - The name of the event which occurred. Cannot be null or empty string.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if eventName is null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if eventName is empty.
        See Also:
        tagEvent(String, java.util.Map, long)

      • tagEvent

        public static void tagEvent(java.lang.String eventName,
            java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> attributes)
        Behaves identically to calling tagEvent(eventName, attributes, 0).
        Parameters:
        eventName - The name of the event which occurred. Cannot be null or empty string.
        attributes - The collection of attributes for this particular event. If this parameter is null or empty, then calling this method has the same effect as calling tagEvent(String). This parameter may not contain null or empty keys or values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if eventName is null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if eventName is empty.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if attributes contains null keys, empty keys, null values, or empty values.
        See Also:
        tagEvent(String, java.util.Map, long)

      • tagEvent

        public static void tagEvent(java.lang.String eventName,
            java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.String> attributes,
            long customerValueIncrease)

        Within the currently open session, tags that event occurred (with optionally included attributes).

        Attributes: Additional key/value pairs with data related to an event. For example, let's say your app displays a dialog with two buttons: OK and Cancel. When the user clicks on one of the buttons, the event might be "button clicked." The attribute key might be "button_label" and the value would either be "OK" or "Cancel" depending on which button was clicked.

        Best Practices
        • DO NOT use events, attributes, or dimensions to record personally identifiable information.
        • The best way to use events is to create all the event strings as predefined constants and only use those. This is more efficient and removes the risk of collecting personal information.
        • Do not tag events inside loops or any other place which gets called frequently. This can cause a lot of data to be stored and uploaded.
        Parameters:
        eventName - The name of the event which occurred. Cannot be null or empty string.
        attributes - The collection of attributes for this particular event. If this parameter is null or empty, then no attributes are recorded and the behavior with respect to attributes is like simply calling tagEvent(String). This parameter may not contain null or empty keys or values.
        customerValueIncrease - Added to customer lifetime value. Try to use lowest possible unit, such as cents for US currency.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if eventName is null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if eventName is empty.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if attributes contains null keys, empty keys, null values, or empty values.

      • tagScreen

        public static void tagScreen(java.lang.String screen)
        Note: This implementation will perform duplicate suppression on two identical screen events that occur in a row within a single session. For example, in the set of screens {"Screen 1", "Screen 1"} the second screen would be suppressed. However in the set {"Screen 1", "Screen 2", "Screen 1"}, no duplicate suppression would occur.
        Parameters:
        screen - Name of the screen that was entered. Cannot be null or the empty string.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if screen is null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if screen is empty.

      • setCustomDimension

        public static void setCustomDimension(int dimension,
                      java.lang.String value)
        Sets the value of a custom dimension. Custom dimensions are dimensions which contain user defined data unlike the predefined dimensions such as carrier, model, and country. Once a value for a custom dimension is set, the device it was set on will continue to upload that value until the value is changed. To clear a value pass null as the value. The proper use of custom dimensions involves defining a dimension with less than ten distinct possible values and assigning it to one of the four available custom dimensions. Once assigned this definition should never be changed without changing the App Key otherwise old installs of the application will pollute new data.
        Parameters:
        dimension - A dimension between 0 and 9.
        value - The value to set for the given dimension.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if dimension is not between 0 and 9.
        See Also:
        getCustomDimension(int)

      • getCustomDimension

        public static java.lang.String getCustomDimension(int dimension)
        Get the current value for a given dimension.
        Parameters:
        dimension - A dimension between 0 and 9.
        Returns:
        The current value for the given dimension.
        See Also:
        setCustomDimension(int, String)

        scope - The scope of the attribute.

      • setInAppMessageDisplayActivity

        public static void setInAppMessageDisplayActivity(FragmentActivity activity)
        Attach the current foreground activity Localytics. The fragment manager associated with each activity is needed for showing the dialog fragment which hosts the marketing dialog. This method gets the fragment manager from the input activity and attaches it with the marketing handler which controls the marketing trigger.
        Parameters:
        activity - The foreground activity, must not be null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if activity is null.
        See Also:
        clearInAppMessageDisplayActivity()

      • clearInAppMessageDisplayActivity

        public static void clearInAppMessageDisplayActivity()
        Opposite from the setInAppMessageDisplayActivity, this method detaches any fragment manager from Localytics.
        See Also:
        #setInAppMessageDisplayActivity(android.support.v4.app.FragmentActivity)

      • setPushDisabled

        public static void setPushDisabled(boolean disable)
        Enable or disable the app from receiving push notifications from Localytics. Should be called only after registerPush(String) has been called.
        Parameters:
        disable - Boolean flag to enable or disable push notifications. Note that true value disables push while a false value enables it.
        See Also:
        isPushDisabled()

        Boolean indicating whether Localytics push notifications have been disabled.

      • handleTestMode

        public static void handleTestMode(Intent intent)
        Handle the intent for push test mode. User can define the correct intent filter in the Manifest.xml file so when they got the mail from Localytics they can enable the marketing test mode or test the marketing push immediately.
        Parameters:
        intent - The same intent object from activity's getIntent method. The intent contains params for push test mode. Cannot be null.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if intent is null.

      • setTestModeEnabled

        public static void setTestModeEnabled(boolean enabled)
        Enable/Disable the test mode with the given flag. If the user is not in the test mode, all marketing-message dialogs will not show once and the information to show the dialog will be deleted after the dialog is closed. In test mode, the information will never be deleted so the same marketing-message dialog will always show under the right condition.
        Parameters:
        enabled - Flag to indicate whether to enable the test mode or not.
        See Also:
        isTestModeEnabled()

      • isTestModeEnabled

        public static boolean isTestModeEnabled()
        Determine whether the test mode is enabled.
        Returns:
        true if the test mode is enabled, otherwise false.
        See Also:
        setTestModeEnabled(boolean)

      • addMessagingListener

        public static void addMessagingListener(MessagingListener listener)
        Add a listener that will be notified of certain in-app messages callbacks:
        • MessagingListener.localyticsWillDisplayInAppMessage()
        • MessagingListener.localyticsDidDisplayInAppMessage()
        • MessagingListener.localyticsWillDismissInAppMessage()
        • MessagingListener.localyticsDidDismissInAppMessage()
        Parameters:
        listener - The object that will receive the callbacks.
        See Also:

      • setIdentifier

        public static void setIdentifier(java.lang.String key,
                 java.lang.String value)
        Record your custom customer data. Once this value is set, the device it was set on will continue to upload that value until the value is changed. To delete the value, pass in null.
        Parameters:
        key - The custom data key.
        value - The value for the key.
